results.title: Warlords II Scenario Builder for DOS
results.material_description: Floppy disk videogame. Three 3 1/2 inch floppy disks, CD-ROM, CD jewel case, registration card, subscription card, catalogue and manual in cardboard box
results.brief_description: Warlords II: Scenario Builder allows for an improved amount of customization to the base Warlords II game. These include the ability to edit the map, add new items, write descriptive text, create new unit and city graphics using a pixel editor and even change specific unit characteristics. 24 new scenarios also come with the pack, including ones that draw from historic sources like Medieval England to more far-fetched situations, like an alien invasion.

results.title: Warlords II Deluxe for DOS
results.material_description: CD-ROM videogame. CD-ROM in CD jewel case
results.brief_description: An updated version of the original game, Warlords II Deluxe adds higher resolution graphics, new terrain types, new scenarios and improved AI. It also allows for the creation of custom tile, army, and city sets for the map. The game is bundled with an improved version of the Warlords II Scenario Builder.
results.description: An updated version of the original game, Warlords II Deluxe adds higher resolution graphics, new terrain types, new scenarios and improved AI. results.title: Super International Cricket for SNES
results.material_description: Cartridge videogame. Cartridge and manual in cardboard box
results.brief_description: A sequel to International Cricket, this improves on the graphics and audio from the previous game. It has eight teams: Sri Lanka, Australia, England, South Africa, New Zealand, India, Pakistan and the West Indies. However, the game lacks official team and player licensing, unlike its predecessor. It also opts for the Australian scoring of the game, as opposed to the international method.

results.title: Stargate for SNES
results.creator_credit: Probe Software, Tantalus Media and Acclaim Entertainment Ltd
results.brief_description: This action platform side-scroller set in the sci-fi universe of Stargate has the player rescuing the slaves of Abydos, defeating the evil villain Ra and getting his team back to Earth using the Stargate device. Most missions involve finding people or items in different locations, while fending off enemies with an upgradable machine gun and grenades. In addition, two missions has the player engaging in plane dogfights in one of Ra’s flying gliders. While the overall mission is to defeat Ra, seven bomb pieces and seven hieroglyphs must be collected beforehand or the player will lose the game even if they defeat Ra.

results.title: Stargate for Game Boy
results.creator_credit: Beam Software and Acclaim Entertainment Ltd
results.material_description: Cartridge videogame. Cartridge and manual in cardboard box
results.brief_description:
Ra, the vicious alien ruler of Abydos, is using Stargates find resource-rich worlds to conquer and enslave its inhabitants. Only the player can stop Ra by cracking the Stargates’ codes and closing them before they can be misused. Stargate, while based on the action sci-fi franchise, is a matching puzzle game, similar to Tetris but with a 3D aspect. Tiles are dropped into a Stargate and matching three tiles with the same symbol clears the tiles. The game is lost when too many tiles fill up the space.

Adding complexity is the “address”, a set of seven symbols across the top of the screen that the player must clear by stacking three tiles of that symbol. The game features two modes. Skill Mode has the player clearing addresses before the tiles fill up. The game’s speed increases as more and more addresses are cleared. In Battle Mode, a player can play against the computer or another player via a link cable to another handheld. Clearing stacks adds them to your opponent’s field, hopefully overwhelming them and winning the match.

results.title: Star Wars Yoda Stories for Game Boy Color
results.creator_credit: Lucasfilm, Ltd., Torus Games and THQ
results.material_description: Cartridge videogame. Cartridge and manual in cardboard box
results.brief_description: Despite being based off of the Star Wars universe, Star Wars: Yoda Stories lacks a central plot or definitive goal. Instead, the game is designed to be infinitely playable in short bursts, where goals are randomly generated and the levels are procedurally made. Despite the variety, the game always starts the same, where the player, as Luke Skywalker, arrives at Dagobah in an X-Wing. Goals are then given by Yoda after he is found.

results.title: South Park Rally for PlayStation
results.creator_credit: Tantalus Media and Acclaim Entertainment Ltd
results.material_description: CD-ROM videogame. CD-ROM and manual in CD jewel case with insert
results.brief_description: Based on the popular TV series, this kart-tyle racing game includes many of the characters from the show’s first two seasons. These include series mainstays like Stan, Kyle, Eric and Kenny to more unique characters like Mr. Garrison, Dr. Mephesto, and Terrance and Phillip, which have to be unlocked. While racing, a player can pick up different coloured boxes with a set of randomised items that can be used to boost the player or hinder other players. Other competitive game modes include variations of tag, collecting special items and delivering objects before other players do. Series creators Matt Stone and Trey Parker were not involved in the development of the game, but did provide voice work for the characters.

results.title: Shadowrun for SNES
results.creator_credit: Beam Software and Data East USA
results.material_description: Cartidge videogame. Cartridge, reference sheet and manual in cardboard box
results.brief_description:
In the early 1990s, Nintendo didn’t allow sex, drugs and alcohol to appear on its consoles. Games also couldn’t show blood or graphic violence. This presented a challenge for Australian developers Beam Software, who were turning the gritty pen-and-paper roleplaying game Shadowrun into a future classic.

So while the protagonist Jake can only order a ‘warm glass of milk’ in a sleazy ‘club’ (‘bars’ weren’t allowed), Beam still managed to deliver a dark neo-noir story true to the original RPG’s seedy cyberpunk world. That world was realised through Beam’s technical innovations, including character masking, an isometric view and a keyword dialogue system previously only seen on PCs.

But it was lead designer Pauli Kidd’s wry and atmospheric writing that ensured the beloved tabletop RPG became one of the most critically acclaimed games of the 1990s.

results.title: The Punisher for NES
results.creator_credit: Beam Software and LJN Entertainment, Inc.
results.material_description: Cartridge videogame. Cartridge, plastic cartridge case, registration card, poster, Nintendo Power advert and manual in cardboard box
results.brief_description: The Punisher puts the player in control of Frank Castle, and his iconic anti-hero persona, The Punisher. The game itself is an on-rails shooter, where the player can move left and right along the screen to avoid enemy gunfire but is otherwise automatically guided through each level. Levels are both packed with enemies and destructible objects, sometimes hiding powerups. These powerups include ammo, armour, grenades, and additional heath. The Punisher has six overall missions with a variety of environments and levels within each. Killing all the enemies in a level gives additional bonuses in the next stage, like extra grenades, ammo and an unlimited ‘super gun’ upgrade. The game ends with a gun and fistfight against the notorious villain Kingpin.

results.title: Powerslide for PC
results.material_description: CD-ROM videogame. CD-ROM in CD jewel case with insert and manual
results.brief_description: After an environmental holocaust killed 98% of the world’s population, the survivors above ground turned to modifying and racing the cars left over in the ruins of civilization. In the ruined world of Powerslide, players race through abandoned cities buried in sand, ruins of a dam, abandoned mine shafts, and other desolate landscapes. Perform death-defying jumps and slide through the corners as you eke out each win! This racing sim has full car dynamics, force feedback, and full multiplayer support.
